Actually you still have a misconception in your video, a very common one that also I had when studying optics in engineering. The horizontal polarization component is not "horizontal" to the reflective surface (not always) or the material interface if is an example of transmited light like in sunglasses. Indeed it is horizontal to the "plane of incidence", a fictional plane defined as the plane that contains the incidence beam, the reflection beam, the transmited beam, and the "normal vector" which is an arbitrary vector that is perpendicular in any direction to the reflective or transmision interface. This is why always exist an horizontal and a vertical polarization independently of the incidence angle of the beam respective the relective surface... are not definied by its orientation to this interface surface.

There may be one more thing to consider when doing a correction video. Best practice for correcting wrong information is to give the correct information without repeating the incorrect claims. People tend to weigh the wrong information equally to the correction when they are both stated at the same time and are less likely to remember which claim is more correct.

A better way to phrase the correction might be something like, "Unlike what we said in the previous video, when light waves bounce off of a horizontal surface they tend to reflect off of it mostly horizontally."

This has become an enormous problem in news communication also when trying to counter misleading assertions by certain politicians. News organizations feel that they have to repeat the incorrect claims by the politician before following with the facts (if they even bother with the facts.) What the public hears is "this news organization says that politician X says Y, there must be some truth to it."

But, the filters don't simply block some light and let other light through, they actually alter the light also. This is because the crystals that absorb the filtered light don't simply get rid of it; the vibrating field caused by the absorption interacts with the light passing through, causing it to be altered. This is why they are polarisING filters, not simply polarisED filters.
